title: Linking up the web of data
displayTitle: Linking up the web of data
body:
The current web is primarily configured as a series of documents. While these documents draw on rich sources of data, they disguise it beneath pages designed for humans to view. In this module, we explore what would happen if you remove these human-friendly documents from the web. Imagine you only had the data, all open, all usable and all interlinked in a big network or 'web' of data.

In this module we introduce the web of open linked data and look at how the 5-Stars of linked open data can help us get there.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • What is the web of data?
  • Web identifiers for physical things
  • Creating a deeply connected web of open linked data

title: Surfing the web of data – in 2 minutes
displayTitle: Surfing the web of data – in 2 minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant introduces athe web of linked open data and examines how the 5-stars of open linked data can help you start surfing the web of data

title: Understanding the web of data
body: The web of linked open data is changing the way we access and browse open data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: What is the web of data?
_items.body:
Think of the current web as a series of documents. These documents are designed (by people) to be visually attractive (for other people) to read and to provide them with information. What these documents are not designed for is to present raw data in a way that both humans and machines can read.

There is a significant difference between data that is ‘on the web’ and the ‘web of data’. Data “‘on the web’ is a file that you download from a document. The web of data is a set of deeply-linked data resources that can be instantly read and understood by both humans and machines.

_items.title: Linking up the web of data
_items.body:
In order to further explore this concept, imagine that the visually-attractive documents were stripped away from the web. How would you find your way around?

You would need signposts to tell you how your current location relates to others around it.

The “web of linked open data” provides just these signposts by requiring that all data be connected via links to other data. These links allow not just you to navigate between data points but, crucially, also allow machines to do so.

_graphic.alt: A graph of open licences across countries
_graphic.title: A graph of open licences across countries

_items.title: What can a web of linked open data do?
_items.body:
We don’t need to imagine what it would be like to navigate the web of data as some parts of it already exists and are deeply connected.

Large corporations like Microsoft have even researched tools that would allow us to navigate this web in a whole new way

_graphic.alt: A map from a to b
_graphic.title: A map from a to b

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes accessible by being available online.

Data becomes useable through being available in a common, understandable machine readable format.

Open data must be licenced. This license must permit the free usage of the data and allow users to transform, combine and share with others, even commercially.

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness. Consider the following:

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
To be open there should be no limitations that prevents any particular use of the data.

A user should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Even though data must be free to use, this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is a cost in creating, maintaining and publishing useable data.

Ideally, any fee for data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to zero for many datasets.

Live data and big data can have ongoing cost related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use it, reuse it and redistribute it, even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However these do not make the data more open.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:

title: Are you ready for open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open data?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about opening your data for users, can you recall them?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses.
data that anyone can access, use and share.
data that is visible on the web.

Open data must also be licenced to allow free usage and must also be available for commercial use.

title: Why do we need open data?
displayTitle: Why do we need open data?
body: What does open data have the power to do?

_items.text: Open data can unlock social, environmental and economic value.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data can transform interaction between governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grow economies and save our planet.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Open data can transform interaction between governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grow economies and save our planet.

title: Open data - Veni, vidi, vici
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is the natural resource for the digital age and, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its use in creating new value.

Open data can transform interaction between governments, businesses and individuals. It has the power to improve services, grow economies and save our planet.

In the next module, we look at how value is unlocked in open data.
